statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

header.gameNote: CONTINENTAL TIRE LAS VEGAS CLASSIC AT LAS VEGAS

article.description: Doug McDermott had 30 points and eight rebounds to lead No. 14 Creighton past Wisconsin 84-74 on Friday night for a spot in the Las Vegas Invitational final.
article.headline: Doug McDermott leads Creighton into Las Vegas Invitational final
article.linkText: McDermott leads Creighton into Las Vegas final

inlines.body:
More Creighton-Wisconsin Coverage

Creighton's finish belied the back-and-forth action in the second half of its win over Wisconsin, Myron Medcalf writes. Blog

article.story: LAS VEGAS -- Doug McDermott and his dad felt differently about the younger McDermott's performance Friday night. His dad's opinion, though, carries more weight. Greg McDermott is No. 14 Creighton's coach. Doug McDermott had 30 points and eight rebounds to lead Creighton past Wisconsin 84-74 for a spot in the Las Vegas Invitational final. "I got off to a slow start (shooting). I missed a lot of shots I normally make," Doug McDermott said. "I need to get to the post. I thought I did a great job in the post. I felt really comfortable being patient and making reads out of the post." Creighton (5-0) will play Arizona State in the championship game Saturday. The Sun Devils beat Arkansas 83-68. "We let Doug go to work," Greg McDermott said. "He made really good decisions. He took what the defense gave him. His pace was better offensively tonight." Ethan Wragge had 17 points, including a 3-pointer that put Creighton up for good, 61-60 with 7:40 left at the Orleans Arena. Austin Chatman added a career-high 14 points for Creighton, which shot 62 percent from the field in the second half and 88 percent from the free throw line for the game. "When you get these opportunities, you've got to take advantage of these opportunities," the coach said of his reserves, who outscored Wisconsin's subs 15-0 in the second half. "We matched their toughness. We wanted to make a statement. Anytime you play a Big Ten team, it's a big game. Wisconsin is unbelievably well coached. When you beat one (of coach Bo Ryan's teams), you earned it." Jared Berggren led the Badgers (3-2) with a career-high 27 points and seven rebounds. Ryan Evans had 15 points and eight rebounds, while George Marshall added 13 points. "I thought we competed pretty well, but (Doug) McDermott was too tough for us," Ryan said. "He has a feel for the game. He makes other guys look like they haven't played before. He's a coach's delight, and his coach happens to be his dad." Wisconsin will play Arkansas in the third-place game. The Bluejays were 22-of-25 from the free throw line and outrebounded Wisconsin 40-34. Creighton trailed 39-38 at halftime, then took a 43-41 lead and went up 55-48 with 13:04 to go. But Wisconsin responded with a 12-3 run before Creighton regained the advantage. The Bluejays later built their largest lead at 11 with less than a minute left. "We'll dissect their film tonight and show (the players) tomorrow morning," Greg McDermott said of Arizona State. "Their guards are a handful. We're definitely facing a totally different team. We'll have to use our bench a little bit earlier. Only half the work is done here." There were seven ties and 13 lead changes in the first half. The Badgers' biggest advantage was 12-6 with 15:32 until halftime. "We didn't do a good job of taking away from them what they do well," Berggren said. "We weren't getting enough stops. We definitely wanted to contain them better defensively." This was the first time the teams had met since 1949, when the Badgers won 75-39. Both coaches faced off in the 2005 NCAA tournament in Oklahoma City. Ryan's Wisconsin team defeated Greg McDermott's Northern Iowa squad 57-52. This was Creighton's first trip to Las Vegas since December 2008, when it won the Las Vegas Classic with wins over Fresno State and DePaul in the final two rounds. Wisconsin had made two trips recently to Las Vegas, losing both to UNLV, the last in November 2010.
